comment.author: 98017360@N00
comment._content: it was a Nash Metropolitan in the picture. it's tiny, roughly the size of a VW bug, and without any emissions controls 41 mpg is not really that difficult to do. Back in 1985 Nissan Sentras were getting gas mileage as good or better than today's Hybrids. Cleaning up emissions robs fuel efficiency.

comment.author: 7354640@N06
comment._content: I remember as a Lad, there were a few of them going around in Scotland, The Austin Metropolitan, they were usually 2 toned Red and White with the spare wheel, built into the boot lid, it was like something from another world.

comment.author: 35188692@N00
comment._content:
and now there are  hardly any..there is a turquoise/ivory one in my neighborhood-a tiny two seater

Nash Metropolitan was a JV of its day with an Austin engine,maybe of 850cc or one liter capacity. probably 40 horsepower
as mentioned it had no emissions controls of any kind..it needed frequent tune-ups or owner attention due to regular battery/ points ignition-probaby had plenty oil leaks and  lighting issues
I loove the simpler times of the 50's

comment.author: 22466178@N02
comment._content: Someone once told me that leaded gasoline also produced more compression,,, im not sure how true that statement was ,,, but you do notice really old cars getting very good gas millage on the older leaded fuels

comment.author: 8543480@N06
comment._content: What the lead does is that it gives a higher octane rating, i.e. it burns more easily. This it is possible to have higher compression without knocking. Alcohol does the same thing and it was the dominating method of octane boosting in Europe until leading (favoured by US companies) became industry standard.

comment.author: 22958680@N05
comment._content: mattface has it right, that car doesn't have any emissions equipment on it, which is why that kind of gas mileage is achievable. often times when trying to make things better, we end up making them worse, IMO.

comment.author: 72253021@N00
comment._content: Those cars were like tanks, didn't need air bags and such in those days. Of course it was before my time.

comment.author: 98017360@N00
comment._content:
That's a pretty romanticized way to look at it, but actually, while most cars back then did weigh a couple of tons, they lacked the sort of saftey engineering that todays cars are required to have. Before the late 60s cars weren't required to have colapsing steering columns which meant that in a front end collision, the steering wheel was very likely to take your head off. Before the 70s when 5mph crash tests were mandated most cars could not sustain an impact with a brick wall at 5mph without taking major damage. Saftey glass windsheilds didn't keep the passengers inside the car, so it was not uncommon to be thrown from the car, and possibly even be run over by your own car. 

The car in the picture is even less safe than those old "tanks" because it was comparatively tiny and lacked modern innovations such as crush zones which help todays small cars keep their passengers safe even when they collide with something much larger. 

Also to adress the fuel efficiency once again. The nash metropolitan got great fuel mileage for it's time because it was tiny, and had a tiny engine. The lack of emissions controls likely allowed it to get better fuel economy, but also those fuel efficiency claims were made before the EPA got in the business of regulating how fuel efficiency is tested, and most manufacturers claims at the time would have been obtained on a test track at a constant speed under ideal conditions purely for marketing purposes. If the Nash Metropolitan were tested and rated by current EPA standards I highly doubt that it would get 40 mpg.

comment.author: 62379908@N00
comment._content: The best kept  secret in those days would really get you some great gas mileage.   The secret?  Lies.

comment.author: 62379908@N00
22958680@N05
comment._content: i agree with you, Howard33. I also wish cars still looked the way they did in the 50's, but with all the modern advancements that cars have today.

comment.author: 98017360@N00
comment._content:
One of those modern advancements was called aerodynamics. Other advancements I mentioned in my earlier comment such as crush zones and the ability to withstand impact at 5mph also have influenced the way mordern cars look.

I agree cars of the 50s looked fabulous, but the primary design concern then was style. We can't really go back without erasing all we now know about how to build better cars. Sure therye are modern cars with retro styling, but you can't just throw a 1950s body on top of a modern chassis. Partly because the modern chassis is part of what's called a unibody design. the body is integrated into the chassis. It allows them to be lighter, more rigid, and to withstand impact better, whereas back then they bodies were just bolted on top of a rolling chassis which consisted of a couple of frame rails, suspension components and wheels.

comment._content: Give me style any day of the week

comment.author: 27851952@N00
comment._content:
As for the mileage, "your mileage may vary"  (YMMV) applied as much back then as now, and were often pretty optimistic.  My father dourly commented that fuel mileage estimates for cars of that period must have been determined with the car going down hill and with a tail wind...

About the only thing cars from that period had going for them was distinctive styling.  Anybody under 50 can't understand how a really good quality bias tire of the time was often worn out at 15,000 miles, the poor handling and lousy drum brakes, the tendency of body panels to rust through in 5 years in the "salt belt," the lack of any safety features beyond the non-shatter windshields, etc.  Photos of the old cars are great, but the new vehicles are a _LOT_ better than they used to be.

comment.author: 27309380@N06
comment._content:
Fuel was leaded then, also the Nash Metropolitan was a rather small car, cute but small. It did get rather good mileage compared it's contemporaries such as big Chevy's and Chrysler's.

I once read an article in a mid 50s issue of Popular Mechanics and there was a story about a man who invented a special carburetor in 1936. It was designed to get a typical family sized car the staggering economy of 700 MPG! Before he was able to develop this major advancement in fuel consumption, it went on to say that men in black suits showed up and confiscated his invention and gave him an ultimatum such as; if you so should ever get this 700 mpg wild hair again, they'd not be so easy on him! The article did feature an illustration of the carb but, sadly no diagrams! 

Could you imagine driving a 1936-56 model car and getting 700 mpg??? Wow, no wonder the oil companies paid that guy a social call! That would send a devastating blow to their money belts!

comment.author: 40708286@N07
comment._content: Some things never change. The body language tells me that the guy is believing the sales rep and the lady is thinking, "buy this and your dead". :)

comment.author: 62379908@N00
comment._content: The 700 mile carb is the mother of all urban legends.  If you got 100% of the energy out of a gallon of gasoline, it wouldn't move two tons that far.
